This Veterans Day, we honor all who have served and reflect on the values that unite us. Gerald Gangaram, Bill of Rights Institute's Vice President of Civic Leadership Development and former aviation officer in Afghanistan, learned firsthand that being American transcends race, religion, or politics. It's about shared principles like freedom, equality, and justice. "This Veterans Day, we should all honor the men and women who sacrificed selflessly to preserve our freedom and principles. We should also remember that we can all wear and defend our values, even if we do not all wear uniforms," says Gangaram. Today, hes helping BRI empower young people with these same values through civic education. Read more in his recent article,  https://lnkd.in/eRgSTQfM.

Talented middle schoolers from across the country are gearing up to put their civic knowledge to the test in Washington, D. C.! The 2024 National Civics Bee National Championship, hosted by The Civic Trust of the U. S. Chamber of Commerce Foundation, takes place on November 12 from 9:30 a.m. to 2:30pmand tuning in couldnt be easier! You can register to attend in person or stream it live online. With finalists from 27 states competing, this annual event builds civics skills and knowledge among young Americans, their families, and communities. The Bill of Rights Institute is proud to support the Bee with study guides and contest materials, and BRI President David Bobb will emcee the group competition on November 11. To learn more and register, visit the National Civics Bee website, here  https://lnkd.in/gbrJehys  #BillofRightsInstitute  #NationalCivicsBee  #CivicEducation

BRI is proud to support the work of United Through Reading, which strengthens military families through the power of shared Storytime. Teachers, homeschoolers, and Storytime supporters are invited to bring Veterans Day to life with virtual Storytime! Enjoy special recordings of Service Members reading age-appropriate stories, giving students a meaningful connection to the men and women of the U. S. Armed Services. United Through Reading, a 35-year-old nonprofit, connects military and veteran families with books, literacy resources, and Storytime recordings, supporting family bonds and literacy no matter the distance.
